I'm sorry? Reverse cancer with electricity? Cancer is genetic mutation, it's not possible to reverse DNA damage that way, the best you can do is to suppress cancerous tissue more than healthy tissue - which probably is what happened in the experiments, but in most real situations I doubt it would do much more than slow down cancer somewhat.
I didn't really hear what mechanism this could theoretically use to help the body fight cancer. Just slowing it down is not enough, it will just relapse, the DNA damage is still there and the cells are not killed.
Furthermore, what mechanism can possibly be used to somewhat-consistently inject photoactive genes into tissues of live people? And then how to remove them if the treatment is ever successful?
Chemotherapy is mostly to kill off and suppress cancer that cannot be easily separated from healthy tissue, this therapy is unlikely to ever replace that because blasting ions indescriminately will, as mentioioned, negatively affect all muscles and nerves, primarily heart, but also stomach, mobility, and all other ones, and for targeted this will not replace radiation or local chemo since it cannot discriminately kill the cancerous cells, just suppress them at best.
By the way, cancer is not one thing, every cancer is different, and although there are similarities, I serously doubt all or almost all cancers behave same way in this regard, which should be at least mentioned.
Although the research itself is interesting, as of now applications are unclear at best, suggesting otherwise is fake news.

1:44 To be as accurate as possible you may want to say "totipotent stem cells" instead of just "stem cells", and to be less accurate, yet acceptable, you may want to say "pluripotent stem cells", as the majority of stem cells in the human body can only differentiate to only certain types of tissue, e.g. hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) can only divide to blood cells. It's possible that some research could take stem cells and revert them to a state of pluripotency, but so you can do to many tissue cells. Please correct me gently if I'm wrong. I only wanted to point this out as many people confuse stem cells for pluripotent stem cells, even when most of the time it's a benign confusion, I think some people may want to know this.

Molecular biologist here. That second study you cited with tadpoles is not really going to be applicable to medicine. Judging by your description, it's safe to assume that the "gene injection" was CRISPR-cas9 which edited the host genome to integrate those genes. Using genetic editing in medicine is something that we are a ways off from utilizing, considering the kind of disastrous side effects it could produce and our current lack of ability to control it

Woah! Degree of caution required here. First off, you shouldn't say this can reverse cancer as if it were a single disease. Second, a lot of what causes or contributes to cancer obviously can't be reversed by changing membrane potential, like DNA damage for instance. I would expect this to be a treatment that works for cancer cells with DNA not too different from the host, but most of the worst kinds of cancer would probably be too unstable for this to work.

Even gene therapy to correct things like diabetes could benefit from the added protection net of being able to stop and reverse cancer.  Yeah, this on it's own is really pretty amazing, but it's not even close to the surface of what could be done BECAUSE of it.
